column1: The Township of East Brunswick was established in 1860. Since January 1
column3: the Township has operated within the Faulkner Act under the Mayor-Council Plan E form of municipal government
column4: which is used in 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the five-member Township Council
column5: with all members elected at-large as part of the November general election in even-numbered years. The mayor and two council seats are up for vote together during Presidential election years
column6: with the other seats up for vote two years later. Serving on a part-time basis as the chief executive of the community
column7: the Mayor votes only in the case of a tie on a vote by the Township Council and can veto ordinances
column8: but vetoes can be overridden by a two-thirds vote of the Council. The Township Council adopts ordinances; adopts a budget after review and revisions; makes appropriations; sets taxes and bond issues; creates and abolishes jobs via ordinance; sets salaries and establishes municipal policy. The Council has the authority to initiate hearings for the purposes of gathering information for ordinance making
column9: airing public problems and supervising the spending of its appropriations.As of 2020
column10: the mayor of East Brunswick is Democrat Dr. Brad J. Cohen
column11: whose term of office ends December 31
column12: 2020. Members of the Township Council are Council President Sterley Stanley (D
column21: James Wendell announced in July 2017 that he was switching parties
column22: giving Democrats control of the Township Council.In February 2014
column23: the Township Council appointed Michael Spadafino to fill the seat expiring in December 2016 that had been held by Nancy Pinkin
column24: until she stepped down the previous month to take office in the New Jersey General Assembly. In the November 2014 general election
column25: Spadafino was elected to serve the balance of the term of office.David Stahl served as mayor from his election in 2012 until his resignation on January 14
column27: when he left office to take on a judge position in nearby Woodbridge Township. The Township Council appointed Kevin McEvoy
column28: a former history teacher at East Brunswick High School and trustee of the East Brunswick Public Schools
column29: to serve the balance of Stahl's term as mayor that expires in December 2016; McEvoy has stated that he will not run to serve a full term as mayor.Republicans took control of the Township Council for the first time in 14 years in 2010

column32: with voter sentiment focused on controversy over a redevelopment plan for a parcel of land known as the "Golden Triangle". Hughes

The township is served by several major roads and highways.The New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95) passes through East Brunswick. The Turnpike's Joyce Kilmer service area is located between interchanges 8A and 9 northbound at milepost 78.7. New Jersey Route 18 connects with the turnpike in East Brunswick and provides connections to New Brunswick
column6: U.S. Route 1 and the Jersey Shore. Major county roads that pass through include CR 527 and CR 535. Other limited access roads are accessible outside the township
column7: such as the Garden State Parkway in neighboring Sayreville and Old Bridge
